fix: keep lost error logs
body:
Very quick fix for redis error getting lost rendering debug of encoding problems almost impossible to be done
Here is an example from the related server

What used to happen in case of encoding problem : 
`Error: FindexError(Conversion("\"insufficient bytes in a word to fit a value of length 163\""))`

What is supposed to happen (thanks to this little 1 line update ) : 
`Error: FindexError(Memory("asba1: REST Request Failed: /indexes/f4052ec7-e374-4e9b-8479-f98d883ae2ac/guarded_write: Database Error: : Memory Error: Response was of incompatible type - TypeError: \"Response has wrong dimension, expected 130, got 129\" (response was binary-data([250, 209, 216, 117, 233, 65, 220, 172, 52, 160, 255, 113, 235, 28, 54, 220, 225, 1, 201, 44, 55, 80, 129, 198, 128, 112, 113, 226, 157, 124, 215, 233, 210, 91, 198, 39, 34, 93, 12, 172, 99, 255, 241, 105, 196, 201, 131, 38, 42, 203, 236, 88, 31, 32, 198, 172, 98, 179, 61, 115, 234, 105, 211, 172, 73, 144, 67, 13, 233, 240, 178, 158, 183, 243, 224, 94, 139, 108, 241, 154, 187, 3, 186, 89, 227, 40, 77, 156, 200, 206, 212, 128, 238, 7, 114, 74, 74, 224, 163, 68, 81, 188, 248, 173, 186, 76, 12, 83, 159, 163, 114, 159, 170, 76, 107, 171, 145, 0, 89, 23, 69, 104, 150, 43, 192, 0, 109, 117, 250]))"))`

title: Small improvements.
body:

- remove a clone when instantiating a Redis memory;
- strengthen the concurrency test by looping `N` times in each concurrent worker
- remove a redundant condition in the g-write script
- remove some unnecessary bounds in the generic tests
- remove redundant documentation (please, refrain your LLM)

title: Feat/findex server v7
body: # PR Overview - generic memory tests - redis store - a new feature : storing the LUA script in the db cache **(this optimization was not reviewed in the previous branch)** - exporting necessary primitives for findex-server (dummy encode & co ) # Info to know This branch is the version of findex that findex server will depend on Direct dependency of this PR : https://github.com/Cosmian/findex-server/pull/20 Almost all the code in this PR was already discussed and reviewed, for reference : - https://github.com/Cosmian/findex/pull/98 -and https://github.com/Cosmian/findex/pull/93 ### PR health check ups - [x] Add modifications of the other PR and close it - [x] Everything compiles - [x] Benches testes to work correctly after the update (too long to run locally but seems to be OK ) - [x] **Added redis DB to the CI** - [x] Tested this new branch on findex-server and nothing has 'changed'

title: Fix/relax async req
body:
Using `#[async_trait]` enforce trait member outputs to implement `Send`, which is not possible when working with WASM in CloudproofRust.

Using `#[async_trait(?Send)]` allows relaxing this constraint.

title: fix: race condition in `fetch_chains()`
body:
If an upsert modifies the ET and a search is performed before the new values are inserted in the CT, the search client derives UIDs that do not exist yet inside the CT and tries fetching them. When trying to recompose the chain, the removed check would raise an error.

Findex only implements eventual consistency between the two tables, thus no error should not be raised.

title: Fix/alloc problem with multi values in fetch entry tables
body:
## [2.0.4] - 2023-05-23

### Bug Fixes

title: Feature/refactoring
Allow Findex to manage several Entry Tables
Fix recursion when stoppping in progress callback
fix: simplify the Findex search algorithm
body:
- remove the recursion
- remove unnecessary filter on the graph insertions
- remove the `max_depth` parameter: avoiding looping on automate cycles is enough to ensure the algorithm will return; an early return can still be asked by the user via the `progress()` callback
- use iterators where possible

This implementations uses one more clone of the input keywords. However, since a useless clone from the previous implementation has been removed, there should be the same nomber of clones in both versions.

title: feat: batch keywords together when calling fetch chains callbacks
body:
## [2.0.2] - 2023-04-21

**This version follows the 2.0.0 since the 2.0.1 version introduced breaking changes we didn't want to include.**

### Changed

- Batch keywords together when calling the fetch chains callback (prevent doing one fetch chains request by keyword)

title: fix: remove calls to `HashMap::remove()`
body:
Rust `HashMap` implementation is based on the SwissTable algorithm, which is optimized for insert and read operations. Thus for small values, it may is preferable to `get()` and `clone()` rather than `remove()`.

The following benchmarks show that removing a `HashMap` entry in order to get the value stored without copy is about 18% slower than getting this value and then to copy it.

There seems to be no time difference between small values of sizes 32 or 64B.

```
Deletion
                        time:   [99.916 ns 101.47 ns 103.25 ns]

Get + clone / value length: 32B
                        time:   [84.808 ns 86.263 ns 88.109 ns]

Get + clone / value length: 64B
                        time:   [84.844 ns 86.027 ns 87.410 ns]
```

Plus, I would argue that using `get()` is less prone to introduce errors when modifying the code since it is not possible to search for a removed value. It also simplifies the reading.

title: feat: use the same parameter order everywhere
body:
- rng
- keys
- label
- data and other parameters

title: Fix/search
body:
- prevent loop when searching through a cyclic keyword graph.
- implement `Copy` for `Uid`
- simplify `EntryTableValue::unchain()`
- delete `EntryTable::unchain()` which may not be a good choice, please give me your opinion on it :)

title: feat: insert blocks by batch
body:
When writting blocks to Chain Table values, write as many blocks as possible by batch using `copy_from_slice` (one `mem_copy` call).

This allows unexpected perf gains:

```
upsert/Indexing 20 keywords
                        time:   [233.29 µs 234.45 µs 235.62 µs]
                        change: [-0.0958% +0.5225% +1.0567%] (p = 0.08 > 0.05)

upsert/Indexing 200 keywords
                        time:   [2.2100 ms 2.2207 ms 2.2316 ms]
                        change: [-2.4507% -1.8761% -1.2349%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

upsert/Indexing 2000 keywords
                        time:   [20.495 ms 20.550 ms 20.605 ms]
                        change: [-14.570% -14.235% -13.909%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
```

title: feat: improve search's fetch chain
body:
When fetching chains from several keywords, mix all chain UIDs before fetching them by batch in parallel.

The previous behavior was to fetch chains keyword by keyword. This could explain the performance loss. Indeed, this led to collect all chain UIDs once in a `HashSet` to mix the chains and then a lookup is needed for each chain value.

```
search/Searching 1 word time:   [7.7007 ms 7.7186 ms 7.7371 ms]
                        change: [+0.1473% +0.5078% +0.8721%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Change within noise threshold.

search/Searching 10 words
                        time:   [7.7945 ms 7.8134 ms 7.8328 ms]
                        change: [-0.0776% +0.2693% +0.6188%] (p = 0.13 > 0.05)
                        No change in performance detected.

search/Searching 100 words
                        time:   [8.8278 ms 8.8515 ms 8.8758 ms]
                        change: [+1.4550% +1.8223% +2.2070%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.

search/Searching 1000 words
                        time:   [19.458 ms 19.508 ms 19.558 ms]
                        change: [+7.8542% +8.2297% +8.6229%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.
```

title: Improve callbacks
body:
- remove `HashSet` in callbacks parameters where it is possible. This
  avoids hashing data where it is not necessary;
- remove references in callback parameters where it is possible. This
  may avoid cloning in the callback implementation.

The performances are greatly improved:

```
search/Searching 1 word time:   [8.6417 ms 8.6586 ms 8.6760 ms]
                        change: [+1.0528% +1.4871% +1.9134%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

search/Searching 10 words
                        time:   [7.5445 ms 7.5692 ms 7.5944 ms]
                        change: [-7.6182% -7.0244% -6.4150%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

search/Searching 100 words
                        time:   [7.5683 ms 7.5908 ms 7.6142 ms]
                        change: [-40.753% -40.385% -40.010%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

search/Searching 1000 words
                        time:   [16.768 ms 16.809 ms 16.852 ms]
                        change: [-28.441% -28.006% -27.590%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

upsert/Indexing 20 keywords
                        time:   [199.43 µs 200.09 µs 200.79 µs]
                        change: [-15.166% -14.656% -14.161%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

upsert/Indexing 200 keywords
                        time:   [1.9258 ms 1.9319 ms 1.9382 ms]
                        change: [-13.512% -13.005% -12.489%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.

upsert/Indexing 2000 keywords
                        time:   [19.937 ms 19.986 ms 20.037 ms]
                        change: [-3.1133% -2.7406% -2.3728%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
```

Edit: the performances are actually deteriorated for the search
```
search/Searching 1 word time:   [7.6593 ms 7.6773 ms 7.6959 ms]
                        change: [+8.4167% +8.7806% +9.1575%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.

search/Searching 10 words
                        time:   [7.8339 ms 7.8553 ms 7.8771 ms]
                        change: [+9.3196% +9.7362% +10.148%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.

search/Searching 100 words
                        time:   [8.7041 ms 8.7246 ms 8.7457 ms]
                        change: [+7.2710% +7.6430% +8.0372%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.

search/Searching 1000 words
                        time:   [18.049 ms 18.093 ms 18.138 ms]
                        change: [+1.9513% +2.3140% +2.6855%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.

upsert/Indexing 20 keywords
                        time:   [199.60 µs 200.32 µs 201.06 µs]
                        change: [-2.0574% -1.5254% -1.0051%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.

upsert/Indexing 200 keywords
                        time:   [1.9194 ms 1.9258 ms 1.9325 ms]
                        change: [-1.4786% -1.0214% -0.5765%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Change within noise threshold.

upsert/Indexing 2000 keywords
                        time:   [20.059 ms 20.109 ms 20.162 ms]
                        change: [-3.2296% -2.8747% -2.5285%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.

```

title: Feature/live compact
Support deletions
body:
Support deleting an indexed value from the list of indexed value of a given keyword.

- the upsert interface now takes as input two distinct lists for the additions and the deletions.
  **Question**: an alternative would be to flag each element of a single list as being an addition or a deletion. I don't know which is the best.
- the Chain Table size is increased by one byte per line.
- the benches have been **improved** (an effort has been made to reduce the overall number of allocations).

Below are given the benches with a comparison to the `feature/add_macros` branch.
```
search/Searching 1 word time:   [10.643 ms 10.676 ms 10.709 ms]
                        change: [-11.934% -11.422% -10.879%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
search/Searching 10 words
                        time:   [10.802 ms 10.832 ms 10.864 ms]
                        change: [-10.606% -10.073% -9.5247%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
search/Searching 100 words
                        time:   [11.752 ms 11.790 ms 11.828 ms]
                        change: [-12.358% -11.833% -11.286%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
search/Searching 1000 words
                        time:   [21.582 ms 21.630 ms 21.679 ms]
                        change: [-3.1334% -2.7810% -2.4431%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
upsert/Indexing 20 keywords
                        time:   [234.91 µs 235.71 µs 236.55 µs]
                        change: [-2.5067% -1.9320% -1.3567%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
upsert/Indexing 200 keywords
                        time:   [2.2661 ms 2.2743 ms 2.2828 ms]
                        change: [-8.9163% -8.3586% -7.8004%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
upsert/Indexing 2000 keywords
                        time:   [24.211 ms 24.287 ms 24.364 ms]
                        change: [-2.8158% -2.3230% -1.8367%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
```

title: refactor!: remove interfaces (ffi, wasm, cloud, pyo3)
Feature/update progress callback
Improve perfs on noisy fetch chains
body:
Since fetchChains is often an IO intensive task, call the futures in parallel instead of calling them one by one can save a lot of time.

This implementation still call in sync for each keyword, we may put the outer loop inside the `join_all(futures)` too to call everything in parallel

We may have problems about the number of requests in parallel in the browser… Currently we send around 900 fetchChains requests in parallel (if it's HTTP, the browser could be not happy at all…)
